newsitem.title: USA: Find toys to grow with your child - expert advises.
newsitem.headline: Find toys to grow with your child - expert advises.

text.p: Nothing costs more than a toy that is never used, or tossed into a corner after five minutes.
Some of the smartest, and money-saving, toy selections are not necessarily the action figure of the moment or highly promoted movie tie-ins.
"Find a toy that will grow with the child, to be used different ways at different ages," said New York-based psychologist Dr. Istar Schwager, adding that no one toy is terriffic for everybody.
Toys that will be used in different ways over time include sets of blocks, puppets and art materials.
It is important when selecting a toy that the purchaser keep in mind the child's age, developmental level, skills and interests, said the consultant to children's media.
Many of the mistakes adults make when giving children gifts comes from having expectations that are too high, and not really understanding developmental levels.
Preschoolers are not ready to understand board games, Schwager said, because they have a hard time dealing with rules and competition.
For them, appropriate toys are those that encourage the imagination, such as blocks and dress up accessories.

By age five or six and up to age nine, children are generally able to play group games, she said. They enjoy practicing new skills, so board games, pick-up sticks, jacks and sports equipment are appropriate.
Pre-teens have distinct interests, such as crafts, art and music. Good gifts support those interests, Schwager said.
Gift givers should always be aware of safety, and it's a wise suggestion to rely on the manufacturer's age guidelines. These are established with a toy's safety and play value in mind.
"Even if a child is precocious, don't get a toy aimed for an older kid," Schwager said.

Computer games, on just about every kid's wish list, "are fine in balance with other activities," Schwager said. "They're not good when they're at the expense of not having other toys to play with -- when they're part of the mix with outdoor, social and time alone activities."
They are appropriate for children aged four or five, "but only at a limited extent," Schwager said.
As for chess, Schwager suggests parents try it with their kids around ages five or six. At this age they are beginning to understand relationships and rules, she said.
